content.text: *ICE seeks police recruits as $45B expansion lags*

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has launched TV recruitment ads to enlist local police, spending $853,745 in the Seattle area since mid-September. Despite $45 billion in new funding under President Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act to nearly triple detention capacity to more than 100,000 beds, reporting says ICE has added little capacity in three months as arrests fell from a June peak. Overcrowding has worsened in short-term holding cells, and a New York City judge ordered immediate improvements at the Lower Manhattan processing center—an accountability step aimed at better conditions.
*Illinois, Chicago sue to block President Trump's Guard deployment*

Illinois and the city of Chicago sued President Trump on Monday to stop his plan to deploy federalised National Guard troops to the city, citing a recent Portland court ruling. In court, it was revealed that troops are already on the way, including hundreds from Texas, after the President authorized 300 Illinois National Guard members 48 hours earlier.
*Virginia AG candidate urged to quit over violent texts*

Virginia’s Democratic attorney general nominee Jay Jones is facing bipartisan backlash after 2022 text messages surfaced in which he talked about shooting then–House Speaker Todd Gilbert. Republican leaders and media figures, including MSNBC's Joe Scarborough, have urged him to step aside. Democrats such as gubernatorial candidate Abigail Spanberger also condemned the messages, underscoring calls for civility in Virginia politics.
*Federal judge blocks Trump's National Guard deployment to Oregon*

A U.S. district judge in Oregon temporarily blocked the Trump administration from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, ruling the plan exceeded statutory authority and intruded on state autonomy under the 10th Amendment. After President Trump moved to send federalized California and Texas Guard units, the judge expanded her order to bar relocating, federalizing, or deploying any state's Guard in Oregon, noting there was no evidence Portland required federal military intervention. The Justice Department is appealing the ruling.
*Supreme Court rejects Ghislaine Maxwell appeal of 2021 conviction*

The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday declined to take up Ghislaine Maxwell’s bid to overturn her 2021 sex trafficking conviction, in an order issued on the first day of the justices’ new term. Maxwell is serving a 20-year prison sentence arising from that case. Her appeal argued that a secret 2007 agreement between prosecutors and Jeffrey Epstein should have shielded her from prosecution.
*Supreme Court hears free speech challenge to Colorado ban*

The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday heard arguments in Chiles v. Salazar, a First Amendment challenge by counselor Kaley Chiles to Colorado’s ban on conversion therapy for minors by licensed professionals. The outcome could shape whether more than 20 states can enforce similar laws. At issue is whether such bans regulate professional conduct or restrict protected speech.
*Israel, Hamas open indirect Egypt talks under Trump plan*

Israel and Hamas began indirect talks in Sharm El Sheikh, Egypt, on Monday, after both sides signaled support for President Trump’s peace plan to end the Gaza war. Hamas said it would accept parts of the 20-point plan, including releasing all remaining Israeli hostages and the remains of those who have died, while Israel has provisionally agreed to the framework. The renewed diplomacy comes two years after Hamas’s Oct. 7, 2023, attacks that ignited the conflict.
*House recess delays Arizona swearing-in, stalling Epstein petition*

Arizona Rep.-elect Adelita Grijalva has not been sworn in two weeks after her special-election win, as House leaders set Oct. 7-13 as a district work period with no floor votes scheduled. The delay also prevents her from signing a petition seeking a House vote to release federal files related to Jeffrey Epstein; supporters say her signature would be the 218th needed. Speaker Mike Johnson has cited the government shutdown and scheduling constraints after previously promising to swear her in early this week.
*FBI reviewed Republican senators' records in January 6 probe*

Republican senators say the FBI in 2023 analyzed phone records of more than a half dozen GOP lawmakers as part of an investigation into efforts by President Trump to overturn the 2020 election. According to those senators, investigators saw only basic call information — dates and times — for several days during the week of January 6, 2021, and did not access call content. A document describing the activity was turned over to Congress and publicly released on Monday by Sen. Chuck Grassley, prompting fresh scrutiny and oversight discussions.
*Investigators: no arson evidence in South Carolina judge’s fire*

Authorities are investigating a fire that destroyed the Edisto Beach home of South Carolina Circuit Court Judge Diane Schafer Goodstein, injuring three people. State officials say they have found no evidence so far that the blaze was intentionally set, while the cause remains under review. First responders used kayaks to aid rescue efforts at the waterfront property, reflecting a swift, resourceful local response.
*Update: Senate blocks funding as Trump conditions health talks*

In the latest development, President Trump first said he was open to working with Democrats on a health care deal tied to the shutdown, then later insisted talks would happen only after Democrats back reopening the government. The Senate on Monday rejected dueling government funding bills, including a GOP "clean" stopgap that failed 52-42 and needed 60 votes, extending the stalemate into its sixth day. Democratic leaders Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries said no negotiations with the White House are underway despite the President’s remarks.
*CBS names Bari Weiss editor-in-chief after Free Press deal*

On Monday, Paramount acquired The Free Press and named its founder, Bari Weiss, editor-in-chief of CBS News in a newly created role. Several outlets reported the purchase price at $150 million, though Boston.com noted no price was announced. In a staff memo, Weiss said she aims to help make CBS "the most trusted news organization in America and the world".
